questions.question: Light entering the eye first passes through
questions.explanation: Light entering the eye first passes through the cornea, then the lens, and finally the retina, where it encounters the retinal ganglion layer, among other layers.

questions.question: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with

options.A: Condensation of opsin with Vitamin A
options.B: Photoisomerization and hydrolysis of visual purple

questions.explanation: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with photoisomerization and hydrolysis of visual purple. Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein-coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process. Phototransduction in rods and cones: Rhodopsin (opsin + retinal) 11-cis Retinal → All-trans Retinal → Metarhodopsin II → Activation of transducin (G protein) → Activation of phosphodiesterase → ↓ cGMP → Closure of Na+ channels → Hyperpolarization → ↓ Synaptic neurotransmitter → Bipolar cell response and other neural responses.

questions.question: Which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to make rhodopsin?
questions.explanation: 11-cis-retinaldehyde combines with opsin to make rhodopsin. All-trans retinol is one form of Vitamin A, which is converted to 11-cis retinol under the influence of isomerase. Finally, 11-cis retinol is converted into 11-cis retinal, which combines with scotopsin to form rhodopsin. questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the distribution of rods and cones in the retina?

options.A: Macula lutea is the blind spot
options.B: Low density of photoreceptors are present in the macula
options.D: Peripheral retina has a greater cones to rods ratio

questions.explanation: Central fovea (foveola) contains only cones (a rod-free area) and is a region of the highest resolution. Regional variations in the retina: Macula lutea, located at the posterior pole, temporal to the optic disc, is an area of central vision with a high density of photoreceptors and interneurons. The optic disc lacks photoreceptors and is called the 'blind spot'. Normally, a person is unaware of the blind spot because the corresponding part of the visual field can be seen by the contralateral eye, and neurological processes complete the incomplete image perceptually. The peripheral retina has a higher ratio of rods to cones (20:1), a greater degree of convergence of photoreceptors to the target interneuron (bipolar cells), more sensitivity to light, and lower visual acuity.

questions.explanation: The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows hyperpolarization. In photoreceptors: When the light strikes the outer segment, a cascade of reactions (refer figure) are initiated, that close some of the Na+ channels in the outer segment and result in hyperpolarization. questions.question: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway?

options.C: Cells in the lateral geniculate body

questions.explanation: Photoreceptors - rods and cones are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.

questions.question: Purely depolarizing cells in the optic pathway are
questions.explanation: The responses of the rods, cones, and horizontal cells are hyperpolarizing, and the responses of the bipolar cells are either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing, whereas amacrine cells produce purely depolarizing potentials.

questions.question: Amacrine cells secrete
questions.explanation: Amacrine cells release acetylcholine. Amacrine cells are one of the neuronal cell types of the retina. They transmit signals in two directions, either directly from bipolar cells to ganglion cells or horizontally within the inner plexiform layer from axons of the bipolar cells to dendrites of the ganglion cells or to other amacrine cells. Amacrine cells release GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine, and indolamine. Other neuronal cell types of the retina are: The photoreceptors: rods and cones, Horizontal cells, Bipolar cells, and Ganglion cells. Of these cell types, only neurotransmitters secreted by photoreceptors and amacrine cells have been discovered. Rods and cones release glutamate at their synapses with the bipolar cells.

questions.question: The only neurons in the retina showing action potential are
questions.explanation: All neural elements in the retina exhibit local graded potentials except ganglion cells, which show action potential.

questions.question: The axons from the lateral geniculate nucleus terminate in

options.D: Layer 5 and 6 of the primary visual cortex

questions.explanation: The axons from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) mostly end in Layer 4. The primary visual receiving area (primary visual cortex) is located principally on the sides of the calcarine fissure and has 6 layers similar to the neocortex. Layer 4 receives most of the input from the LGN, which is divided further into 4A, 4B, 4Cα, and 4Cβ. The magnocellular pathways from layers 1 and 2 of the LGN end in layer 4Cα while the parvocellular pathways from layers 3-6 of the LGN end in layer 4Cβ.

questions.question: Auditory information is relayed throughthalamic nucleus.
questions.explanation: The medial geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys auditory information from thebrainstem to the primary auditory cortex.Lateral geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys visual information.

questions.question: In the auditory pathway, which is the first structure that can determine the direction of the perceived sound?
questions.explanation: The superior olivary nuclei receive information from both ears and begin the process of detecting the direction from which a sound comes. The eighth nerves reach their respective cochlear nuclei in the medulla, from where the nerves travel to both the ipsilateral and contralateral superior olivary nuclei in the pons, and hence giving it the ability to detect the direction of the sound. The lateral part of the superior olivary nucleus does so by comparing the difference in intensities of sound reaching the two ears, whereas the medial part of the superior olivary nucleus detects the time lag between the signals entering the two ears.

questions.question: Which of the following events prompts the auditory system to interpret a sound as loud?

options.A: A decreased number of inner hair cells become stimulated
options.B: A decreased number of outer hair cells become stimulated
options.C: Hair cells excite nerve endings at a diminished rate
options.D: The amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases

questions.explanation: There are at least three ways that the auditory system determines loudness: • As the sound becomes louder, the amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases so that hair cells excite the nerve endings at more rapid rates. • As the amplitude increases, more and more hair cells on the fringes of the resonating portion of the basilar membrane become stimulated. • As the amplitude of vibration reaches high intensity, the outer hair cells become recruited at a significant rate.

questions.question: Umami taste is evoked by
questions.explanation: Umami taste is triggered particularly by the monosodium glutamate (MSG) used so extensively in Asian cooking. Taste Receptors • Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter, and umami. • The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types: • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): for salt and sour taste • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): for sweet, bitter, and umami • Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) • Na+ movement through ENaC → salt taste • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste • Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs • T1R2 and T1R3 families → sweet taste • T2R family → bitter taste • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) → Umami

questions.question: Mitral cells are seen in

questions.question: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.explanation: The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the light reflex, where, illumination of the blind half of the retinashows no pupillary reaction while stimulating the normal side of the retina shows a pupillaryreaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilisand tumours of the optic thalamus.255Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in botheyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the opticchiasma.256
